prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would. A box contains 5 white balls and 6 black balls.  Five balls are drawn out of the box at random.  What is the probability that they all are white?
solution: There are $\binom{11}{5} = 462$ ways to choose 5 balls out of the box.  There is only $\binom{5}{5} = 1$ way to choose 5 white balls out of 5.  This means that the probability that all 5 balls are white is $\boxed{\dfrac{1}{462}}$.
gpt_response:
The first thing you need to do is figure out how many total balls are in the box. Since there are 5 white balls and 6 black balls, the total number of balls in the box is 5 + 6 = 11.

Next, you need to figure out how many ways you can draw 5 balls out of 11. This is a combination problem, so you need to use the formula nCr = n! / r!(n-r)!. In this case, n = 11 and r = 5, so the number of ways to draw 5 balls out of 11 is 11C5 = 11! / 5!(11-5)! = 462.

Lastly, you need to figure out how many ways you can draw 5 white balls from the box. Since there are 5 white balls and you are drawing 5 balls in total, there is only 1 way to draw all white balls.

Therefore, the probability of drawing all white balls is 1/462, or approximately 0.00216450216.
